header_summary:
The release candidate for Bitcoin Core version 30.0 (v30.0rc1) has been announced by fanquake, signaling an important step towards the new major version release. This version, alongside its binaries and source code, is accessible for review and testing, with detailed release notes and a testing guide provided to facilitate the evaluation process. Feedback and issues can be reported via the designated GitHub issue tracker, with the release candidate transitioning to a final version contingent on the identification of no significant problems. For more information, binaries and source code can be accessed at [Bitcoin Core's official page](https://bitcoincore.org/bin/bitcoin-core-30.0/test.rc1/) and [GitHub](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/tree/v30.0rc1), respectively.

In parallel, the Bitcoin development community continues to engage in collaborative efforts to enhance the network's functionality, as demonstrated by a workshop hosted by Michael Zaikin on the ctv-csfs-activation IRC channel. This session focused on discussing the Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP), exploring its use cases, and creating transactions, with workshop logs made available for those unable to attend. The next workshop, scheduled for 18 September 2025, aims to further examine the creation of different types of pools using CTV and CSFS. The collaborative spirit and ongoing commitment to technical examination and knowledge sharing are fundamental to the progression of Bitcoin development, as highlighted by the workshop's details [here](https://ctv-csfs-workshops.github.io/bip348/logs).

Moreover, the recent release of Bitcoin Core version 29.1 introduces various bug fixes, performance enhancements, and updated translations, aiming to improve the security and functionality of Bitcoin transactions and operations. This update, which supports a broad range of operating systems, addresses mempool policy changes, logging rate limits, and wallet and peer-to-peer functionality improvements. It underscores the collective effort of contributors in advancing the Bitcoin Core project through code contributions, testing, documentation, and translation work. Further information about this release can be found at [delvingbitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/bitcoin-core-v29-1-released/1978).

Lastly, jonasnick has shared a comprehensive cryptography workbook developed for an interactive workshop focusing on Bitcoin cryptography. This resource, designed to enhance understanding and application of cryptographic principles within Bitcoin, covers a wide range of topics from introductory concepts to advanced cryptographic signatures. The workbook's emphasis on practical exercises and real-world application, alongside its role as a platform for pioneering cryptographic research, reflects its significance as an educational tool within the community. The workbook is available for download, and feedback for further refinement is welcomed at [this GitHub link](https://github.com/cryptography-camp/workbook/releases).

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core 30.0 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary:
- The Bitcoin Core version v30.0rc1 release candidate is now available.
- Feedback for this release candidate can be submitted on GitHub's issue tracker.
- If no significant problems arise, v30.0rc1 will officially become version v30.0.

recent_posts.title: IRC logs: BIP 348 Workshop
recent_posts.summary:
- Michael Zaikin led a CHECKSIGFROMSTACK workshop for Bitcoin developers on Libera.
- The workshop focused on exploring BIP, its use cases, and creating transactions.
- A follow-up workshop on 18 September 2025 will discuss creating pools with CTV and CSFS.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v30.0 release candidate is available
recent_posts.summary: - Bitcoin Core v30.0rc1 binaries are now available for download.  - Preliminary release notes and a testing guide are accessible online.  - Feedback for this release candidate can be submitted on GitHub.

recent_posts.title: Bitcoin Core v29.1 Released
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin Core version 29.1 introduces significant updates including bug fixes and performance enhancements.
- It encourages users to upgrade for improved functionality and security, supporting a range of operating systems.
- Key updates include a mempool policy change, rate-limited disk logging, and improvements to wallet and P2P functionalities.

recent_posts.title: Provable Cryptography for Bitcoin: An Introduction (Workbook)
recent_posts.summary:
- The workbook focuses on Bitcoin cryptography for an interactive workshop and is downloadable from GitHub.
- It covers a range of topics, including algorithms and discrete logarithms, to enhance understanding of cryptographic signatures.
- Feedback and contributions are welcomed to improve this educational resource on cryptographic principles.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] Add BIP-0093 (Codex32) as application to BIP-0085
active_posts.summary:
- Ben Westgate proposes integrating BIP-0093 with BIP-0085 for deterministic wallet backups.
- Codex32 under BIP-93 aims to enhance BIP-32 seed backups with error correction and secret sharing.
- He highlights codex32's benefits, seeking community feedback for broader adoption and Bitcoin Core integration.

active_posts.title: [BIP Proposal] OP_TWEAKADD
active_posts.summary:
- Jeremy proposed a new Bitcoin opcode, OP_TWEAKADD, for enhanced scripting capabilities.
- The opcode design prioritizes push semantics and flexible implementation of tweaks.
- Feedback from the Bitcoin development community is encouraged for further refinement.

active_posts.title: BIP Booby Trapped Wallets - Covenant-Only Taproot Outputs
active_posts.summary:
- Matias Monteagudo proposes enhancing Bitcoin wallet security through covenant-only Taproot outputs.
- The proposal adds an optional security layer for institutional Bitcoins, requiring script-path spending.
- It includes technical specifications, backward compatibility, and focuses on deterring unauthorized access.

active_posts.title: Sharing block templates
active_posts.summary:
- Recent Bitcoin node and miner mempool policies include full replace-by-fee and enhanced spam filters.
- Compact block relay has significantly reduced block propagation times to nearly zero.
- Template sharing and weak blocks have been proposed to improve network efficiency and robustness.

active_posts.title: SwiftSync -- Speeding up IBD with pre-generated hints (PoC)
active_posts.summary:
- The SwiftSync write-up provides a deep analysis of its implementation and `assumevalid` mechanics.
- It details a safeguard strategy against inflation risks, maintaining monetary policy integrity.
- The document explores SwiftSync's transaction order validation and introduces scalability improvements.

active_posts.title: Addressing community concerns and objections regarding my recent proposal to relax Bitcoin Core's standardness limits on OP_RETURN outputs
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal to modify `OP_RETURN` output limits in Bitcoin has ignited community debate.
- Critics worry about misuse for large-scale storage, despite the proposal aiming to enhance network efficiency.
- The discussion highlights broader Bitcoin governance and decision-making process challenges.

today_in_history_posts.title: A Replacement for RBF and CPFP: Non-Destructive TXID Dependencies for Fee Sponsoring
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Jeremy shared a draft to replace CPFP and RBF to enhance Bitcoin transaction fees.
- The mechanism aims to prevent denial of service by ensuring transactions sponsor fees.
- It includes strict rules and a preliminary implementation, though not carefully audited.

today_in_history_posts.title: Why should funders always pay on-chain fees?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A debate in the Lightning Network suggests fundees share commit-tx fees to avoid trust issues.
- The proposal includes having nodes pay for HTLCs they offer, impacting fee allocation.
- Concerns arise over increased complexity and potential negative effects despite long-term benefits.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant tools softfork
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- The softfork proposes activation of BIP-118, BIP-119, and BIP-345 to enhance Bitcoin security and efficiency.
- BIP-345's rapid deployment for creating Bitcoin vaults has gained interest for its custodial safety benefits.
- With 7,000 lines of code, the manageable deployment of BIP-345 is anticipated, pending community consensus and feedback.
